article.title: Towards Teleoperation with Human-like Dynamics: Human Use of Elastic Tools

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variable "G" represent in this figure?
choices: The duration of the back-swing phase.
The maximum angular velocity of the handle.
The gain calculated by dividing peak hammer head velocity by peak handle velocity.
The difference between peak hammer head velocity and peak handle velocity.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which leaf-spring stiffness resulted in the highest median peak hammer velocity?
What does the "relative gain" in this figure represent?
choices: The percentage of the achievable gain with a perfect velocity source that the participants reached.
The difference in gain between the flexible conditions and the rigid condition.
The increase in gain compared to the first trial of each condition.
The gain achieved by participants using their non-dominant hand.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this figure suggest about the learning effect of using the elastic hammer across all conditions?
choices: There is a significant and consistent improvement in gain throughout the learning phase.
Participants show a steep learning curve in the first 20 trials, followed by a plateau.
The learning effect is minimal, with most participants achieving their best performance early in the learning phase.
Performance deteriorates after approximately 70 trials, likely due to fatigue.
